summary: The U.S. District Court for the District of Utah today entered a final judgment against Gregory Emmanuel Williams, Jr., a convicted felon who pled guilty to three separate felony property crimes, and sentenced him to prison instead of probation.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Salt Lake City, Utah, alleges that Williams violated his rights against double jeopardy and abused its discretion by sentencing him to a sentence that was improperly enhanced from a class A felony to a felony.  According to the complaint, Williams was on probation for the 2014 vehicular burglary, which had been entered as a third-degree felony, when the district court initially imposed a zero-to-five-year prison term and sentenced Williams to probation instead of prison.  As alleged, Williams had no reasonable expectation of finality in the sentence he was sentenced to, and the court did not consider all of the legally relevant factors necessary for a sentence to be effective.  Williams also alleges that the court improperly imposed a five-year sentence on him for burglary of a vehicle, when he had already served two prior probationary sentences.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for Utah today announced criminal charges against Williams arising from the same 2015 incidents.  On November 2, 2017, the Honorable Rebecca M. Welshhans issued a final sentencing order that permanently enjoins Williams from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders Williams to pay a civil penalty of $75,000.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Williams consented to the entry of a judgment permanently enjoining him from future violations of the double jeopardy provisions of the federal securities laws, and ordering him to pay $25,000 in disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and a $10,000 civil penalty.  Additionally, Williams agreed to be permanently enjoined from associating with any third- or fourth-tier criminal organization, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and to be barred from serving as an officer or director of a public company for five years.  He also agreed to a one-year officer-director bar and to a three-year conduct-based injunction prohibiting him from participating in any type of substance-abuse treatment program.  Finally, the court agreed to send Williams to prison on a one year-and-one-day basis.  It also ordered Williams to participate in an inpatient treatment program for opioid addiction, which is subject to court approval.   The court also agreed not to impose a penalty of zero to five years, which would be subject to a court-ordered suspension of
